cons: There are several factors that make the Illinois Institute of Technology a terrible place to work as a Ph.D. researcher. Toxic work culture. Illinois Tech has a toxic work culture, with bullying, harassment, and discrimination which creates a hostile and unpleasant environment for researchers to work in. Lack of financial support. Illinois Tech does not provide adequate support to its Ph.D. researchers, such as funding, equipment, or access to necessary research instruments, which makes Ph.D. research much more difficult and frustrating. There is no communication. If you discuss your issues with deans of department, nobody cares, and no reaction they have to your serious issues and problems they can easily cut your stipend and put you under pressure to accept their toxic work culture or leave the university. They totally don't care about losing a Ph.D. student, even senior Ph.D. students.

review_title: Be prepared to sell your plasma...
pros: Very collaborative and intellectually enriching environment to work in. Being a graduate student and TAing/RAing is enjoyable for the most part. Over your summer you can pick up an additional RA stipend i the $6000-8000 range, if your PI is willing. Generally a friendly environment, lacking the perils of more cut-throat universities. You stand a good chance of getting a good learning experience in a lot of good labs (very few bad labs).
cons: You will work at least 60 hours a week for peanuts (typical for a grad student), all the while treated it as though they are graciously spoiling you (a little atypical, especially considering just how low the pay is). That stipend has not increased in many years (5+), but be prepared for the "squeeze," as administrative fees and health insurance come out of that stipend. The insurance has gone up about 20-25% for each of the past three years, and administrative fees by 5% annually. In 2016 I gave back $3000 of that stipend. My experience suggests you will continue to give back more each year; so as your workload increases, your financial resources shrink. Any way you slice it, the compensation isn't competitive in Chicago, or even on par with a rural schools like UI-Urbana or UW-Madison, despite a significantly higher cost of living. I hope you like shared room apartments and microwave ramen.

review_title: Working at IIT is one of Chicago's Best Kept Secrets
pros:
It's one of Chicago's best kept secrets as an institution of higher learning and as a place to work.  It continues its long-held tradition of attracting serious, shy and exceptionally bright students.  

IIT is trying to be a positive and involved member of the Bronzeville community--in both its redevelopment and revitalization.  IIT seems to have a much better relationship with its neighbors than many urban universities have with their neighbors--something that IIT should be proud of.

Because of IIT's relatively smaller size and budget, there's a much stronger entrepreneurial spirit.
cons: Campus improvements, such as in Infrastructure, tend to take longer to come about due to budget limitations.

review_title: Good Engineering School with a few problems
pros: If you're an undergrad majored in engineering, IIT is definitely a good school to consider. IIT provides a lot of opportunities for undergrads to get involved with research through the try-outs in the lab, senior research projects and academic seminars and conferences. It also give people the chance to get in touch with the industries in the early stage through company sponsored or involved R&D projects.
cons: Some issues may also cause concerns about this wonderful school. First is the limited budget: it may not be an uncommon issue for many universities in America in these days, but limited budget does affect largely on both research and student life from the outdated equipment to the outdated school facilities (like the gym). Second is small and outdated library: the small library in the main campus can hardly satisfy students who're in need of large amount of knowledge for researches, although the iShare system across the campuses in Chicago can make up for the disadvantage to some extent.

pros: Learning a new location and seeing the possibilities of what I can do to get the campus rocking, following the Meis plan and watching the changes happen! and working with the students were fun
cons:
Mid management was a joke.  Everything done last minute or too late {Reactive).  Did't follow industry standards on anything having to do with the landscape season. Thinks like blowing out the sprinkler system by the end of September, but ,no, we waited until the first snow and made it a whole lot of fun.  Plus,l wonder how many pipes are damaged since we waited?  Probably $10,000 in damage,mid managers hand book was You Tube video, plus, he didn't have a clue if it worked at all.  In addition to this craziness, I started asking for salt in early September and it finally arrived a day after the snow event.

The crew is totally afraid of a management,  they would promise the world and they do not follow through with anything.  They use quilt and anger to run the crews.  Finally, something to remember, This management does not care of your home life!  So, if you have an issue good luck leaving.

If you do things right, you can walk out of that university with two or three years of managerial experience and then go on to a professional job.
cons:
They will withhold a certain amount of your stipend from each bi-monthly payment and give it to you at the end of the academic year, if and only if, you fulfill your contractual obligations (which are more subjective than you might think). They are decidedly going to choose profit over your wellbeing. 

Terrible communication between departments, terrible communication intra-departmentally as well. Residence and Greek Life (RGL) is particularly bad at this. They still heavily favor their RAs over the Desk Managers even though Desk Managers have a greater impact on the university in both the immediate and long term.

review_title: One of the worst professional experiences I could imagine
pros: There are some truly wonderful people there who love education and what they do. I believe in the university and respect the students and many members of the faculty.
cons: There are many departments with excellent leadership and true vision. The two departments I worked for, Marketing and Graduate Admissions, are not so lucky. Avoid if at all possible. Morale is horrible. The senior leadership's treatment of their employees is borderline abusive. Retribution, petty grudges, insider politics, and backstabbing are all too common amongst the managers. HR is currently getting involved, so maybe things will shape up soon. There is also little hope for advancement since the job structures are very static. A select few people do advance, beyond their skill level, but only through nepotism. Not every department is like this, but I would proceed with caution.

pros:
- Generally supportive environment that provides a lot of professional development.  
- Most departments allow for space to be innovative and creative.  Not an environment where everyone needs to 'stay in their lane' to be successful.   Entry level employees will have chance to get a variety of professional experiences.
- Probably the best 403(b) match program in the region
- Small campus allows for strong relationships among staff and faculty
- Work-life balance is valued.
- Diversity in the student body exposes everyone to a lot of different cultures and viewpoints!
cons:
- Staffing runs lean, meaning everyone is wearing a lot of hats and can be overwhelming depending on the department.
- Like a lot of higher ed institutions, things can become siloed between departments and between student services and academic departments.  
- A higher level of accountability would help the institution to be more efficient and effective.
- Pay may lag regional market in some departments.

pros:
IIT is a university with vast potential. I loved my time there. 
Typically a very pleasant  work environment.
Lots to do, easy to be a shining star for the shamefully rare dedicated worker.
Depending on where you and what you do, the workload is probably do-able.
cons:
High level leadership is mediocre.

There's plenty of employees that take advantage of the relaxed work environment, which ultimately means when things need to get done there's only a few people willing and able to do it. 

As in all universities, it is difficult to navigate the muddy waters of bureaucracy.

There will be a lack of advancement potential, no matter where you land.

pros:
Greg Pulliam, the Associate Chair of Humanities, was supportive and helpful. After assigning me with my classes and giving me a rundown of the department I was on my own. 

The pay for an adjunct instructor ($3500/course) is better than most in the Chicagoland area and the students were motivated to get good grades. Unfortunately, that was typically there only concern. Nevertheless, they were friendly and easy to work with in the classroom.

Once the semester began there was no oversight from the department so I was free to conduct my courses as I wished.
cons: This is not necessarily a con but the department provided no guidance once the semester began. They seemed to be relieved to have another adjunct faculty member to cover a couple courses and didn't care about what was going on in the classroom as long as the students didn't complain.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Chicago, IL
pros: Benefits were ok but that was all.
cons: Very political. Extremely unethical management especially in the financial aid office. It's all about who you know although the leadership are not qualified for the positions. Experienced gender discrimination being the only guy in the office. They do not apply all of the financial aid laws to assist students. If I had the money I would have sued the college. This was an incredible hostile environment and the HR department was useless. I resigned an still was able to collect unemployment because of the evidence I had against the financial aid department. If you end up working there save all the emails. They do not like to be confronted thus they write everything in email. My recommendation stay away.

job_title: Teaching & Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Most of professors at IIT work on interdisciplinary topics so that working in a research for them provides one with a multi-disciplinary perspective. This in turn, helps one to be more equipped with the needs of the industry and academia.
cons: The facilities in the library might be enhanced for the students so that they can have private rooms for quit research and study and or groups to accomplish assignments together.

job_title: Professor of Aerospace Engineering in Chicago, IL
pros: Illinois Institute of Technology is an exceptional place to work. As a professor in the aerospace and mechanical engineering department you will have ample resources to carry out research in your particular field of expertise. State of the art equipment is abundant. Collaborations with major industry companies are also prevalent.
cons: One of the downsides of working at Illinois Institute of Technology would have to be acquiring funding to do your research. The money is there but it can sometimes take a while to get disbursed. Although this is rarely the case it does happen from time to time. Other than that, I can see nothing wrong with Illinois Institute of Technology.

pros:
Illinois Institute of Technology is a national, technological, Ph.D.-granting research university, with world-renowned programs in engineering, architecture, the sciences, humanities, psychology, business, law, and design.

Founded in 1940 and tracing its roots back to the 1890s with the foundings of Armour Institute of Technology and Lewis Institute, IIT brings a focused, interdisciplinary approach to education, including the Interprofessional Projects Program.

With five campuses throughout the Chicago area and alumni around the world, IIT pairs the educational and cultural experiences of America's Second City with the small feel of an undergraduate population of just over 2300 and total population of just over 7400.
cons: Tuition fee is a bit high but considering the fame and research facilities overall it is a good university.

review_title: Do not work here, there is no management support. This place is great is you are right out of school and want to learn.
job_title: Senior Support Scientist/Engineer in Bedford Park, IL
pros: Tuition reimbursement, work closely with FDA.  Great benefits  as well.  Could be a great place for someone not looking to be a CEO just the normal run of the mill lab  tech.
cons: Definitely had a cast system in place. Unless you can keep your head down and do what your told, that means no suggestions or original ideas, keep looking.  Also the relationship they have with The FDA is toxic. You will be berated and there will be nothing you can do about it.

review_title: Overall good experience, some major downsides
pros: The people are friendly, and the benefits are great. It's pretty much impossible to be fired or laid off.
cons:
Bureaucracy. There is no way, without fighting for a very long time to get a real raise. For software development industry, that's unheard of.

People are in positions that in other companies would have been let go a long time ago. Sadly the bureaucracy makes it that they will never be let go. So there is a culture of routing around those people.

pros: You have a lot of control over the content of the course in the humanities department. There are no observations.  They continue employment based on student evaluations.
cons: The pay is well above the national average per course for adjuncting ($3800), however, when they are charging students 42k a year to go there, we all could get paid WAY more.  IN other departments they make at least 5.2k a course.  IIT doesn't respect its Humanities department.

pros: I liked working as a teaching assistant. The experience was great since I was in contact with both students and professors. I may was lucky but the two professors I worked with were really kind with me at the beginning. The work load is limited to 20 hours a week which can be a good thing if you study in the meantime and a shortcoming if you'd like to make more money.
cons: As I said, the work load is limited to 20 hours, so it limits the pay. For some people the scheduling may be inconvenient since you usually don't have full days.

review_title: Working at IIT was a lesson in patience and learning how to survive micro-management by incompetent senior leadership.

People are promoted based on whether they are married or not and whether they suck up to the right manager, but rarely based on their talents or skills. Those who are less threatening to management are either generally ignored or promoted beyond their capabilities. Those who are assertive are belittled and ultimately driven out.
